ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

INCOME TAX RELIEFS
FOR AGED PARENTS


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Finance if he will consider introducing amending legislation to allow income tax reliefs to tax-payers who are maintaining their aged parents.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, in Asian societies, the support of aged parents is an acknowledged responsibility of all decent citizens. Indeed, Confucius has elevated this into a basic ethical principle, and Chinese classical literature is replete with examples of outstanding acts of filial piety. In these circumstances, it would be unworthy of us to introduce mercenary considerations such as relief from income tax.

    Sir, if this approach does not appeal to the hon. Member, may I add a less traditionalist argument? An International Monetary Fund mission has recently examined our tax system and has stated that our tax reliefs are overgenerous and could with advantage be reduced.

Column: 85

PROPERTY TAX
(Notices for payment)


    2. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Finance (a) whether notices for payment of property tax on attap or wooden houses are sent annually to the house-owners so as to avoid their having to pay accumulated arrears for as many as five years' tax in one payment; and (b) whether he is aware that some such house-owners who had been ordered to demolish their houses have had to pay five years' arrears of property tax.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, notices for payment of property tax in respect of known attap or wooden houses are sent out half-yearly, although, in law, property owners are required to pay property tax in respect of their property without demand.

Column: 86



    Sir, it is known that there had been, cases of landlords who, with a view to evading property tax, had let out their property and collected rents without informing the tax department and without paying property tax. When these cases were discovered, these landlords were made to pay the property tax due, notwithstanding the fact that the property in question was under an order for demolition.

Column: 86

HOUSING LOANS TO CIVIL
SERVANTS
(Particulars)


    3. Mr N. Govindasamy asked the Minister for Finance (a) how many applications have been received from, civil servants for loans to purchase houses built by private developers from 1st January, 1964, up to the latest convenient date, and the total amount of the loans applied for; (b) how many of the applications have been approved, and what is the total amount of the loans granted; (c) what are the reasons or grounds for rejecting an application; and (d) whether he will consider relaxing the rules governing applications for housing loans by granting loans to civil servants who are already living in their own houses and who wish to exchange their existing houses for bigger ones.

    Mr Tang See Chim (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is as follows:

    (a) Up to 30th September, 1969, 992 applications for loans amounting to $22,721,460 were received.

    (b) A total of 771 applications for loans amounting to $16,775,770 were approved. Ninety-two applications for loans amounting to $2,013,400 were withdrawn. Thirty-five applications for loans amounting to $810,180 are under consideration.

Column: 87



    (c) Applications are rejected where the applicant is ineligible under the Government Officers' Housing Loan Scheme, e.g. where the applicant already owns a house, and has previously been granted a loan to purchase a house.

    (d) Each case is considered on its merits. As a general rule, because the interest rates are low and the Scheme is intended to assist those who do not own houses, the exchanging of houses for bigger ones is not allowed, unless there are exceptional circumstances.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Sir, it is not a question of exchanging a house. What would be the answer in the case of an officer who having had a housing loan now sells the house with the intention of buying another?

    Mr Tang See Chim: As I said, Mr Speaker, Sir, the interest rates for housing loans are very low. Also, these loans are primarily meant to help Government officers who do not own houses. If they already had housing loans, normally their applications would not be approved unless there were special circumstances.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary enlighten. me on what the "special circumstances" are before an officer is entitled to a second loan?

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, each application will be considered on its merits. Unless the applicant lists his special circumstances, I will not be able to tell the Member whether or not the application will be approved. But if he has any particular application in mind, perhaps he will send it to the appropriate authority who will no doubt consider it.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan (Crawford): Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary inform the House of any example of

Column: 88

"special circumstances" that has been applied in such a case?

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, all cases will be considered on their merits. Unless the Member can give a particular case, I cannot really answer his question. To do so would, in fact, just be an academic exercise.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, is there any discrimination between lowly-paid and highly-paid Government officers in the consideration of housing loans?

    Mr Tang See Chim: I do not think so, Sir.

FREE PRIMARY EDUCATION FOR CHILDREN OF NON-CITIZEN
PERMANENT RESIDENTS


    4. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Education whether free primary education will be given to children born in the Republic of parents who are non-citizens but are permanent residents.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, children born in the Republic prior to 16th September, 1963, are eligible for free primary education. Children born in the Republic on or after 16th September, 1963, are eligible (in accordance with the Constitution of the Republic in respect of citizenship) for free primary education only if at least one of the parents is a Singapore citizen. However, those born in the Republic on or after 16th September, 1963, of non-citizen parents, at least one of whom has been permanently residing in the Republic prior to 1st January, 1966, will be required to pay the old rate of school fees, which is only $2.50 per month.

Column: 88

UNIVERSITY NIGHT COURSES FOR WORKING CLASS


    5. Mr Lee Teck Him asked the Minister for Education if he will examine the feasibility of the running of university courses at night to afford young working-class people the opportunity to do a university course.

Column: 89



    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, our university education has expanded at a considerable speed recently, and with the reorganisation that is taking place, it would be desirable for our universities to consolidate their existing commitments and to expand further only in those areas which are to serve the more urgent needs of the Republic.

    Though university resources are at present limited in terms of finance and staff, the University Extra-mural Studies Department has been organising courses for the last six years to fulfil the needs of persons who are already in employment. The Adult Education Board also runs further education classes to afford young working-class people the opportunity of further education.

    Mr Lee Teck Him (Ulu Pandan)(In Mandarin): Sir, does the Government intend to organise night courses at the universities to cater for the young working-class people?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have just given two reasons why it is not feasible to run night courses at the universities.

DISCIPLINARY ACTION AGAINST OFFICIALS AND TEAMS FOR
BAD
CONDUCT IN TOURNAMENTS


    6. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Education what action has been taken to deal with (i) players and officials who beat up referees at tournaments sponsored by the Schools' Sports Council at both school and district levels; and (ii) school teams which displayed bad conduct at national tournaments; and what measures have been taken to prevent similar occurrences.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, as far as this Ministry is aware, there was only one incident in the Basketball National Championship Tournament sponsored by the Combined Schools' Sports Council this year. The referee's decision during a keenly-contested match between two schools was not well received by some spectators. In the melee that ensued when the

Column: 90

spectators invaded the court, a coach was alleged to have assaulted the referee. The coach denied this allegation of assault, but nevertheless apologised to the referee concerned.

    The Basketball Convenors Committee has recommended to the Singapore Combined Secondary Schools' Sports Council that in future tournaments:

    (a) Officials and players must adhere strictly to the decision of the referee. A team will be disqualified for the whole tournament if any violence breaks out as a result of the non-acceptance of the referee's decision.

    (b) Principals must place great emphasis on good sportsmanship and discipline among their teachers, pupils and players throughout the tournament.

These recommendations were conveyed to all school principals.

    My Ministry takes a very serious view of any misconduct by teachers and pupils during sports competitions. In future, such misbehaviour will be dealt with severely and any teacher or pupil found guilty may be dismissed from service or expelled from school.

Column: 90

SCHOOL TRAFFIC WARDENS
(Delays in payment)


    7. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware that there are delays in payments to school traffic wardens, and if he will look into the matter.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, school traffic wardens are paid twice monthly and the majority of the claims for payment are sent to the Ministry by post on the 1st and 16th of each month. Payment is made to principals by cheques sent by post. Delays in payment largely arise from late submission of claims or mistakes in claims which have to be returned to the schools for rectification. There were some delays earlier

Column: 91

in the year as a result of the transfer of responsibility to this Ministry from the Police, when new arrangements had to be made for submission and processing of claim forms. However, now that the system has been in operation for some months, delays are minimal. For instance, this month, as of the 10th, there were only 15 late submissions in respect of 151 claims for the second half of September 1969.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Sir, can the Minister ask his Ministry to prepare the salaries for school traffic wardens a month in advance?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: I certainly will consider that suggestion from the Member.

Column: 91

PAYA LEBAR INTERNATIONAL
AIRPORT
(Luggage storage facilities and luggage clearance)


    8. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Communications (a) if consideration will be given to providing luggage storage facilities for transit passengers at the Paya Lebar International Airport; and (b) if he will look into ways and means to speed up the clearance of luggage at the arrival channels.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, air passengers who remain inside the Transit Lounge of our Paya Lebar Airport do not require luggage storage facilities as their baggage would be transferred directly from one aircraft to another by the airlines concerned. However, for those transit passengers who go through the arrival formalities, there are two rooms in the Arrival Block to keep their baggage. If they do not wish to leave their baggage in these rooms, they will have to make separate arrangements with the airline offices concerned at the Airport.

    The baggage of arriving passengers is, at present, being handled by three different organisations. Our Department

Column: 92

of Civil Aviation handles the baggage of seven airlines, K.L.M. handles two (including its own) and Malaysia-Singapore Airlines 14. As this arrangement is unsatisfactory, a study is afoot for the early formation of a separate company to handle the baggage of all arriving and departing passengers at Paya Lebar Airport.

    Our Department of Civil Aviation is also planning to install at least two more conveyor belts in the Arrival Block (making a total of four) in order to speed up the conveyance of baggage to the Customs examination area after they have been taken off the aircraft. The work will be carried out as soon as plans for certain modifications to the existing terminal building have been finalised. When completed, it will be possible for passengers to claim their own baggage from the conveyor belts, thus speeding up the movement of baggage at the arrival channels.

Column: 92

DRIVING LICENCES


    9. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Communications if he will consider the issuing of a more durable driving licence and including the date of first issue in it.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Our new driving licence is made of good quality paper (rag paper) which, if carefully handled, should easily last up to its renewal date, be it one year or three years' time, as the case may be.

    It has been suggested, however, that our driving licences could perhaps be plasticized, as in the case of our identity cards. I have given instructions for such a feasibility study to be made. One problem immediately presents itself. Should we decide to issue plastic-type driving licences, it will be necessary to do so at a central place whereas, at present, for the convenience of the public, we have already decentralised the renewal of driving licences whereby a person can renew his driving licence on the spot at any of 15 specified post offices.

    Another practical difficulty is that sometimes particulars in the driving

Column: 93

licence have to be altered; for example, disqualification of the driver from driving a certain class of vehicle. With the plastic driving licence, it would be difficult to effect such an amendment on it.

    As regards the question of the inclusion of the date of first issue in the driving licence, there are certain practical difficulties which must be pointed out. The present driving licence is a composite one authorising its holder, if he has passed the relevant test, to drive a number of classes of vehicles such as motorcycle, motorcar, heavy motorcar, motor tractor, etc. The dates of authorisation for the driver to drive the various classes of vehicles are likely to be different and it is not possible to record these dates on the driving licence without having to produce an oversized driving licence.

    Should a person desire to know the date of original issue for personal reasons or for the purpose of providing prospective employers with references as to his driving experience, this information, if so required, may be obtained from the Registrar of Vehicles Department on payment of a nominal search fee of $2.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong (Mountbatten): Rag paper, as its name implies, is not a good paper. However, is the Minister aware that even up till today some police constables do not recognise this new licence? Has the police force been informed of the change?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: We are responsible for issuing the driving licences. Perhaps my colleague, the Minister for Defence, will follow up on what the Member for Mountbatten has said about the police force?

    The Minister for Defence (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am unaware that members of the police force do not recognise the new licence. Can the hon. Member mention any specific case?

Column: 94

TAXI DRIVERS AND TAXI
LICENCES


    10. Mr N. Govindasamy asked the Minister for Communications if he will consider (a) taking steps to enforce more strictly and effectively the regulation that no taxi-driver can refuse a fare on the ground that the passenger's intended journey is too short; and (b) issuing more taxi licences in order to provide more employment opportunities and also to discourage taxi-drivers from refusing a passenger because of the shortness of the intended journey.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, up to 1959, an Enforcement Section (comprising 51 inspectors) in the Registrar of Vehicles Department was responsible for carrying out enforcement duties in respect of recalcitrant taxi-drivers, etc. However, because of frequent allegations of corruption and high handedness against this Enforcement Section, it was dissolved in that year - ten years ago. Since then, the enforcement functions in respect of public service vehicles have been placed in the hands of the Traffic Police.

    At present, taxi-drivers who refuse fares on the ground that the passenger's intended journey is too short are suspended from driving for a specified period, ranging from one week to one month, and the Transport Advisory Board is currently looking into this problem with a view to finding more effective ways of dealing with such offenders.

    I am waiting for the recommendations of the Transport Advisory Board on the subject whether or not it is desirable to issue more taxi licences, and Government's decision will be made known at the appropriate time.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I believe the Enforcement Section was closed down in 1959 as a result of allegations against it. Is there a move by the Ministry to employ vehicle inspectors to see that taxi-drivers do not refuse a passenger's fare if he wants to go only a short distance?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I have already indicated in my answer that the

Column: 95

Transport Advisory Board is looking into this problem. Whether or not it will recommend the reintroduction of this Enforcement Section should be left entirely to the Board.

SINGAPORE BADMINTON TEAM
(Improvement of standard)


    11. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Social Affairs what measures will be taken to improve the standard of the national Badminton Team.

    The Minister of Social Affairs (Inche Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker, Sir, the role of the Sports Division of the Ministry of Social Affairs is to render whatever assistance that is needed by national sports bodies in promoting their particular sport. This includes assistance in obtaining coaches of repute, both locally and abroad, provision of supplementary funds and finding suitable venues for training.

    In February 1968, Mr Wong Peng Soon was employed by the Sports Division of my Ministry to train the most promising badminton players with a view to entering for the Thomas Cup Championship in 1969 and 1972.

    Although there was a request for an open trial to decide the final composition of the Thomas Cup Team, it was decided that since Mr Wong had been appointed full time specifically to train the most promising players for the Zone Finals in the Thomas Cup in 1969, and that he had been coaching the Thomas Cup Squad or the national Badminton Team for well over a year, the final composition of the team would best be left in his hands.

    I have no doubt that the experience gained from Singapore's participation in the last Thomas Cup matches in New Zealand will be put to good use.

PUBLIC UTILITIES BOARD
(Complaints of low water pressure)


    12. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the

Column: 96

Public Utilities Board (a) whether the Board has received any complaints by residents in Jalan Perisai, St. Joseph's Lane and Holy Innocents Lane of low water pressure in these areas; (b) whether any action has been taken to ascertain the causes; and (c) whether any remedial actions have been taken.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, not even one complaint of low water pressure in Jalan Perisai or St. Joseph's Lane or Holy Innocents Lane has been received by the Public Utilities Board other than the representation made by the hon. Member on behalf of the residents in these areas. It has been ascertained that the water pressure in Jalan Perisai was and still is satisfactory. But the water pressure in St. Joseph's Lane and Holy Innocents Lane was low due to inadequate sub-mains and consumers' service pipes. Remedial action has been taken by the Public Utilities Board by extending the existing two and a quarter inch sub-main at St. Joseph's Lane by about 500 feet at a cost of $1,000, and by laying a new six-inch main about 1,625 feet long at a cost of $19,000 in Holy Innocents Lane. The water pressure in these areas is now satisfactory.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am surprised that the Minister's reply indicated that no complaint came from the residents in the three areas mentioned. Would he be interested to ascertain from the Board that such written complaints by the residents of Holy Innocents Lane were submitted to the relevant authorities, through me, as far back as last year?

    Mr Speaker: Mr Ng, perhaps you did not hear the first part of the Minister's reply. Would the Minister like to repeat it?

    Mr Barker: Perhaps there is some misunderstanding here. I did say that complaints were received from the hon. Member made, of course, on behalf of the residents in the district. He represents them. Apparently he is doing good

Column: 97

work! He has complained and the complaints have not been attended to. But my understanding of the matter is that no complaints were made direct by the residents to the Public Utilities Board. I do not think we need split hairs on this point.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, it is true that the complaints were made through me. However, can the Minister enlighten the House whether there have been any complaints of low water pressure in areas other than the three mentioned by me?

    Mr Speaker: Are you in a position to answer that question now, Mr Barker?

    Mr Barker: I am afraid I do not know of other complaints, Sir. The Public Utilities Board supplies water throughout the island, and not only to the outpost of Punggol. But if there are other low water pressure areas in Punggol, I hope the Member will bring them to the attention of the Public Utilities Board or to me. There are always low water pressure areas in Singapore due either to repairs of pipes or maintenance service of our filtration plants at Woodlands and Bukit Timah. But it is the practice of the Public Utilities Board to give notice of any repairs that are about to be undertaken.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Is the Minister aware that these complaints were not attended to immediately? Also, can he say when the complaints in the areas mentioned were submitted to the relevant authorities and when action was taken'?

    Mr Barker: Sir, I am afraid I cannot now supply the Member with details. But the point here is that the complaints had been attended to, and if the Member had wanted the work to be done more expeditiously, he could have taken the matter up direct with me.

PROPERTY ACQUISITION
(Payment of compensation)


    13. Mr Lee Teck Him asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether he will consider the

Column: 98

payment of reasonable compensation when acquiring lands and houses.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development (National Development Division) (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Land Acquisition Act, 1966, Government pays reasonable compensation to owners of lands and houses when their property is acquired.

    The principles for the determination of compensation are provided in section 33 of the Act. The Member may recall that the provisions of the Act were considered by a Select Committee. The Committee also considered representations from various quarters before the Bill was passed. Owners of lands and houses to be acquired are given reasonable and just compensation in accordance with the Act. Furthermore, under this Act, the owners concerned have the right to appeal if they are not satisfied with the compensation given to them.

    Moreover, under this Act, if a person has a temporary house or fruit trees in somebody else's land, he too would get compensation under the rehousing scheme.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary in his explanation mentioned the Land Acquisition Act, 1966. Of course, I dare not oppose that law. But the Government should give reasonable compensation. It acquires lands at a very low price but sells them at a high price. There is no provision in the Act prohibiting such practice of the Government. The Government does not take into consideration the present market price of lands. There is a great difference in the present market price of land as compared to that in 1961.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Lee, what is your supplementary question, please?

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, I wanted to say that the law on acquisition of lands should have provisions to the effect that the Government must not pay compensation at a low
